occurrences.line_text: And carried her beyond all ieopardy,
And ouerbore beyond his crouper quight,
But in my way a little here beyond
Nor so did Biblis spend her pining hart,
Did stay a while their greedy bickerment,
When fairer faces were bid standen by:
And bid her ioy of that her happie brood;
And bid them sleepe in euerlasting peace.
Bid thee to them thy fruitlesse labours yield,
Ne gaue him leaue to bid that aged sire
And bid them strike the marke, which he had eyde,
Yet list them bid their businesse to vnfold,
And bid his faithlesse chickens ouerronne
For great compassion of their sorrow, bid
No need to bid her fast away to flie;
And pacing fairely forth, did bid all haile,
And bid him eate, henceforth he oft shall hungry sit.
Great cheare, like one vnto a banquet bid;
Sternely did bid him quickely thence auaunt,
Sweet slo[m]bring deaw, the which to sleepe them biddes.
Thou biddest me to eeke? Can Night defray
Whose secret filth good manners biddeth not be told.
Bidding his beades all day for his trespas,
Bidding the Dwarfe with him to bring away
And ruefull plaints, me bidding guiltlesse bloud to spare?
All night she spent in bidding of her bedes,
As bidding bold defiance to his foeman neare.
He stayd not for more bidding, but away
Bidding his winged vessell fairely forward fly.
Bidding them nigher draw vnto the shore;
And bidding her sit downe, to rest her faint
Bidding her feare no more her foeman vilde,
Bidding them fight for honour of their loue,
Yet for no bidding, nor for being shent,
Bidding him turne againe, false traytour knight,
She at his bidding meekely did arise,
With blustring breath of heauen, that none can bide,
Whose like he neuer saw, he durst not bide,
Her hoped pray, she would no lenger bide,
Or fly away, or bide alone behind:
Or bide the chaunce at thine owne ieoperdie.
By euery fornace many feends did bide,
Or bide him battell without further treat.
For who nill bide the burden of distresse,
Could bide the force of that enchaunted speare,
He by his former combate would not bide,
Or bide the horror of his wreakfull hand,
To bide what iudgement ye shall vs afford.
He will not bide the daunger of such dread,
That substance is eterne, and bideth so,
He bids thee to him send for his intent
Yet thus perforce he bids me do, or die.
And bids thee be aduized for the best,
So bids thee well to fare, Thy neither friend, nor foe, Fidessa.
Them on her bulwarke beares, and bids them nought auaile.
And oft of secret ill bids vs beware:
Who scornes thy ydle scoffe, and bids thee be defyde.
Whereof he taking oddes, streight bids him dight
Yet since thou bidst, thy pleasure shalbe donne.
And with big thundring voyce reuyld him lowd;
In his big base them fitly answered,
Whose big embodied braunches shall not lin,
Bigge looking like a doughtie Doucepere,
That his bigge hart loth'd so vncomely vew.
The cruell steele so greedily doth bight
His harder hide would neither perce, nor bight,
That first did teach the cursed steele to bight
Sitting alone, his bitter lips did bight,
All were the beame in bignesse like a mast,
And downe to Plutoes house are come biliue:
A forrest bill, which both his hands did straine;
The warie foule his bill doth backward wring;
His tombling billowes rolls with gentle rore:
That bloud-red billowes like a walled front
The rolling billowes beat the ragged shore,
His fierie face in billowes of the west,
Meetes two contrary billowes by the way,
Through the dull billowes thicke as troubled mire,
Yet still he bet the water, and the billowes dasht.
Whiles the salt brine out of the billowes sprong.
The waues come rolling, and the billowes rore
Ye might haue seene the frothy billowes fry
The sunny beames, which on the billowes bet,
Why do thy cruell billowes beat so strong,
Eftsoones the roaring billowes still abid,
Is built of hollow billowes heaped hye,
The roaring billowes in their proud disdaine,
That all men feare to tempt his billowes strong,
The roring billowes beat his bowre so boystrously.
The raging billowes, that on euery syde
As when two billowes in the Irish sowndes,
The powre to rule the billowes, and the waues to tame.
And oft to grone with billowes beating from the maine.
Whilest thus amidst the billowes beating of her
And proue thy manhood on the billowes vayne.
With bils and glayues making a dreadfull luster;
Right well Sir knight ye haue aduised bin,
Dead long ygoe I wote thou haddest bin,
The pitteous pray of his fierce crueltie haue bin.
To plaine of wrongs, which had committed bin
By which the mightiest things efforced bin:
Sith which it had bin here preseru'd in store,
Which in th'earthes hollow caues hath long bin hid,
And now together on their way they bin,
BON FONT: but bon that once had written bin,
Where haue ye all this while bin wandring, where bene weft?
His scrip did hang, in which his needments he did bind.
My conscience cleare with guilty bands would bind?
Which to confirme, and fast to bind their league,
Guyon does Furor bind in chaines,
With hundred yron chaines he did him bind,
To bind their doers, to receiue their meede?
That man to hard conditions to bind,
She with her scarfe did bind the wound fro[m] cold to keepe.
That with thy charmes the sharpest sight doest bind,
And to her seruice bind each liuing creature;
Therewith to bind lasciuious desire,
In which his Ladies colours were, did bind
Me seemes the gentle hart should most assured bind.
And there in chaynes her cruelly did bind,
And now they doe with captiue bands him bind;
For by the holy vow, which me doth bind,
They binden vp so wisely, as they may,
Whom neither dread of God, that deuils bindes,
For vertue is the band, that bindeth harts most sure.
Binding her sister, she to him ran hastily.
The Birch for shaftes, the Sallow for the mill,
Of flyes vpon a birchen bough doth cluster,
No braunch, whereon a fine bird did not sit:
No bird, but did her shrill notes sweetly sing;
And she more sweet, then any bird on bough,
Vpon her fist the bird, which shonneth vew,
As when Ioues harnesse-bearing Bird from hie
The bird, that knowes not the false fowlers call,
Each bird his mate, ne any does enuie
As glad of that small rest, as Bird of tempest gon.
That euery bird and beast awarned made,
Whiles the proud Bird ruffing his fethers wyde,
Thus long this gentle bird to him did vse,
All vnawares the bird, when she did find
But that sweet bird departing, flew forth right
But the swift bird obayd not her behest,
Doth beat vpon the gentle bird in vaine,
The bird, that warned Peter of his fall,
Into a bird it chaung'd, and from him past,
In which he liu'd alone, like carelesse bird in cage.
Caught like the bird, which gazing still on others stands.
Ioying to heare the birdes sweete harmony,
They all as glad, as birdes of ioyous Prime,
Birdes, voyces, instruments, windes, waters, all agree.
The ioyous birdes shrouded in chearefull shade,
He ceast, and then gan all the quire of birdes
And all the while sweet birdes thereto applide
The whiles the ioyous birdes make their pastime
Wherein the cherefull birds of sundry kind
Therein the mery birds of euery sort
Trees, braunches, birds, and songs were framed fit,
And all the quire of birds did sweetly sing,
And Cormoyrants, with birds of rauenous race,
And fatall birds about them flocked were,
In which the birds song many a louely lay
Some made for beasts, some made for birds to weare,
And oft young birds, which he had taught to sing
First doe the merry birds, thy prety pages
Charmes to the birds full many a pleasant lay,
The birds to catch, or fishes to beguyle:
Spredding pauilions for the birds to bowre,
And by her stately portance, borne of heauenly birth.
The birth of faire Belphoebe and
Then came Nobilitie of birth, that bread
Ne ought but deare Bisaltis ay could make him glad.
And thrise three times did fast from any bit:
His stubborne steed with curbed canon bit,
The yron rowels into frothy fome he bit.
And smot, and bit, and kickt, and scratcht, and rent,
And bit his tawny beard to shew his raging ire.
On his broad shield, bit not, but glauncing fell
And pierced to the skin, but bit no more,
But bit his lip for felonous despight,
With iron bit, and maketh him abide,
It bit the earth for very fell despight,
And th'one hand seizing on his golden bit,
But by the shoulder him so sore he bit,
That glauncing on her shoulder plate, it bit
Doth runne at randon, and with furious bit
Abasht at his rebuke, that bit her neare,
Bit him behind, that long the marke was to be read.
Him heedlesse bit, the whiles he was thereof secure.
Thereat frown'd Coridon, and his lip closely bit.
Or bit them with his banefull teeth of iniury.
He grind, hee bit, he scratcht, he venim threw,
The fish that once was caught, new bait will hardly bite.
But had no powre in his soft flesh to bite:
He tombling downe, with gnashing teeth did bite
Like as a curre doth felly bite and teare
She feeling him thus bite vpon the bayt,
He sore doth wound, and bite, and cruelly torment.
That none of them in his soft flesh did bite,
That where they bite, it booteth not to weene
Feeling some curre behinde his heeles to bite,
To see her sore lament, and bite her tender lip.
Gan him to hale, and teare, and scratch, and bite;
And bet abacke, threatning in vaine to bite,
And eke the biting of that harmefull Beast
Barking and biting all that him doe bate,
That on their rustie bits did champ, as they were wood.
His bare thin cheekes for want of better bits,
Are quite deuourd, and brought to nought by little bits?
His angry steede did chide his foming bitt,
The Mirrhe sweete bleeding in the bitter wound,
And bitter anguish of his guiltie sight,
That keepes thy body from the bitter fit;
Where Boreas doth blow full bitter bleake,
Her tender brest in bitter teares all night,
That causd her shed so many a bitter teare,
Bitter despight, with rancours rusty knife,
And nourish bloudy vengeaunce in his bitter mind.
And him before, I saw with bitter eyes
They pas the bitter waues of Acheron,
Wherewith he all enrag'd, these bitter speaches said.
Begin, and end the bitter balefull stound;
Long tost with stormes, and bet with bitter wind,
Soone as I thinke vpon my bitter bale:
Haue felt the bitter dint of his auenging blade.
Embost with bale, and bitter byting griefe,
That makes fraile flesh to feare the bitter waue?
And bitter Penance with an yron whip,
O man haue mind of that last bitter throw;
The bitter doome of death and balefull mone
With bitter sense of his deepe rooted ill,
When he these bitter byting words had red,
And after, many bitter throbs did throw
The bitter pangs, that doth your heart infest.
In that knights heart, and wordes with bitter teares did steepe.
Sad be the sights, and bitter fruits of warre,
And eke the Hag with many a bitter threat,
Her bitter rayling and foule reuilement,
Streight gan he him reuile, and bitter rate,
Sonne (said he then) let be thy bitter scorne,
Sitting alone, his bitter lips did bight,
A song of bale and bitter sorrow sings,
And trees of bitter Gall, and Heben sad,
And seuen times dipped in the bitter waue
He cast betwene to ward the bitter stound:
And exercise most bitter tyranny
That bitter stownd, but turning quicke aside
And commen to his reskew, ere his bitter bane.
For whose deare sake full many a bitter stownd,
First did it shew the bitter balefull stowre,
But with hart-thrilling throbs and bitter stowre,
Whose root and stalke so bitter yet did tast,
And tyrannizeth in the bitter smarts
From the worlds end, through many a bitter stowre:
Tho full of bitter griefe and pensiue thought,
Thou art the root and nurse of bitter cares,
So them with bitter words he stird to bloudy ire.
The bitter earth, and bad to let him in
Approching, with bold words and bitter threat,
Gan blowen vp a bitter stormy blast,
But did his hart with bitter thoughts engore,
And fostred vp with bitter milke of tine,
Vntroubled of vile feare, or bitter fell.
At last forth breaking into bitter plaintes
Each other of loues bitter fruit despoile.
The deare compassion of whose bitter fit
Seuen moneths he so her kept in bitter smart,
All carelesse of his taunt and bitter rayle,
And gan this bitter answere to him make;
Harts grief, and bitter gall away to chace,
Couered with cloudie storme and bitter showre,
And adding anguish to the bitter wound,
Of bitter thoughts, which deepe therein infixed lay.
And breathed forth with blast of bitter wind;
All which he did from bitter bondage free,
And that same bitter corsiue, which did eat
With many bitter teares shed from his blubbred eyne.
With bitter taunts, and termes of vile disgrace.
With bitter strokes it both began, and ended.
Not onely into bitter termes forth brust,
Miscalling me by many a bitter name,
And bitter curses, horrible to tell,
With bitter rage and fell contention,
And still among most bitter wordes they spake,
Of that faire bootie, and with bitter wracke
To wype his wounds, and ease their bitter payning.
And bring vs bale and bitter sorrowings,
And all the night for bitter anguish weepe,
He bad him stand, t'abide the bitter stoure
But most that curre barking with bitter sownd,
The bitter anguish of their sharpe disease,
Not sparing him with bitter words to taunt;
And other whiles with bitter mockes and mowes
Which Shepheards lead, without debate or bitter strife.
Blew vp a bitter storme of foule aduersity.
With bitter termes of shamefull infamy;
And euer hastie Night he blamed bitterlie.
And all the while Duessa wept full bitterly.
And eke blaspheming heauen bitterly,
Till that the Palmer gan full bitterly
To be vniustly blamd, and bitterly reuilde.
Gan both enuy, and bitterly to ban;
And with sharpe words did bitterly vpbrayd;
Strife; and debate, bloudshed, and bitternesse,
While teares stood in his eies, few drops of bitternesse.
Vp to the throat, that oft with bitternesse
And gan t'augment her bitternesse much more:
For as a Bittur in the Eagles claw,
A streame of cole black bloud forth gushed fro[m]; her corse.
Whiles sad Night ouer him her ma[n]tle black doth spred
Doest thou sit wayling by black Stygian lake,
Of these poore folk, whose soules with black dishonor
His brode black wings had through the heauens wyde
And ouer all a blacke stole she did throw,
A floud of poyson horrible and blacke,
Deformed monsters, fowle, and blacke as inke,
An aged Sire, in long blacke weedes yclad,
He bad awake blacke Plutoes griesly Dame,
Cast a blacke stole, most like to seeme for Vna fit.
The blacke infernall Furies doen aslake:
Arayd in habit blacke, and amis thin,
Who rough, and blacke, and filthy did appeare,
And in a foule blacke pitchie mantle clad,
Her twyfold Teme, of which two blacke as pitch,
Bespotted all with shields of red and blacke,
A gushing riuer of blacke goarie blood,
A comely Palmer, clad in blacke attire,
With his blacke Palmer, that him guided still.
With that blacke Palmer, his most trusty guide;
But the Blacke Palmer suffred still to stond,
Enwrapped in fowle smoke and clouds more blacke then Iet.
More fit amongst blacke fiendes, then men to haue his place.
But direfull deadly blacke both leafe and bloom,
Dead sleeping Poppy, and blacke Hellebore,
In a blacke flood which flow'd about it round;
And vnder the blacke vele of guilty Night,
Thy dwelling is, in Herebus blacke hous,
(Blacke Herebus thy husband is the foe
Vnder thy mantle blacke there hidden lye,
As white seemes fairer, macht with blacke attone;
By strong enchauntments and blacke Magicke leare,
Full blacke and griesly did his face appeare,
Is cal'de Blacke water, and the Liffar deep,
Within his mouth a blacke spot doth appeare,
Enwallow'd in his owne blacke bloudy gore,
Breathing out clouds of sulphure fowle and blacke,
With which his locks, as blacke as pitchy night,
His mother was the blacke-browd Cymoent,
That seemed some blacksmith dwelt in that desert grou[n]d.
His name was Care; a blacksmith by his trade,
Was nothing left, but like an emptie bladder was.
Her dried dugs, like bladders lacking wind,
And with his trenchand blade her boldly kept
He sought all round about, his thirstie blade
With sonnes owne blade, her fowle reproches spoke;
That scarsely could he weeld his bootlesse single blade.
Thereby his mortall blade full comely hong
Haue felt the bitter dint of his auenging blade.
Out of the earth, with blade all burning bright
And high aduauncing his bloud-thirstie blade,
His sparkling blade about his head he blest,
And fiercely tooke his trenchand blade in hand,
High brandishing his bright deaw-burning blade,
Inflam'd with wrath, his raging blade he heft,
And shyning blade vnsheathd, with which he ran
Betweene them both, by conduct of his blade.
When I at her my murdrous blade did bend,
With his bright blade did smite at him so fell,
And soone his dreadfull blade about he cast,
Or where hath he hong vp his mortall blade,
But Guyons angry blade so fierce did play
Then hurling vp his harmefull blade on hye,
He stroke so hugely with his borrowd blade,
And them perforce withheld with threatned blade,
So braue returning, with his brandisht blade,
His speares default to mend with cruell blade;
Threatning the point of her auenging blade,
A net in th'one hand, and a rustie blade
And fiercely forth her mortall blade she drew,
And snatching forth his direfull deadly blade,
And garnisht all with gold vpon the blade
How euer gay their blossome or their blade
For with his trenchant blade at the next blow
And swearing faith to either on his blade,
Vpon the Image with his naked blade
And laying hand vpon his wrathfull blade,
And fiercely drawing forth his blade, doth sweare,
And burning blades about their heads do blesse,
To see their blades so greedily imbrew,
But soone the knights with their bright-burning blades
Their wrathfull blades downe fell out of their hand,
And cruell blades yet steeming with whot bloud,
Whose footsteps Bladud following in arts
Which Bladud made by Magick art of yore,
Vnder blake stole hyding her bayted hooke,
Did follow that ensample, which he blam'd afore.
The Squire her loues, and being blam'd
To be vniustly blamd, and bitterly reuilde.
One while she blam'd her selfe; another whyle
Now brought her selfe, and blam'd her noble blood:
And lifting vp his lompish head, with blame
And glauncing downe his shield, from blame him fairely blest.
Least thou of her beleeue too lightly blame,
In holy righteousnesse, without rebuke or blame.
And often blame the too importune fate,
And fairly quite him of th'imputed blame,
Cleare as the skie, withouten blame or blot,
First her restraine from her reprochfull blame,
As he to her, withouten blot or blame,
Certes, Sir knight, ye bene too much to blame,
Ne blame your honour with so shamefull vaunt
Resolu'd to put away that loathly blame,
And knew them how to order without blame,
How is it, that this mood in me ye blame,
Right well recur'd, and did away that blame
Vnited all his powres to purge himselfe from blame.
His toward perill and vntoward blame,
And laid the blame, not to his carriage,
Certes (said she) then bene ye sixe to blame,
Here haue I cause, in men iust blame to find,
A gentle knight with so vnknightly blame:
Or euer do, that mote deseruen blame:
For she was pure from blame of sinfull blot,
As those ye blame, yet may it nought appease
That when old Glauce saw, for feare least blame
Ne naturall affection faultlesse blame,
No spot of blame, though spite did oft assay
Lest she with blame her honor should attaint,
Then tell (quoth Blandamour) and feare no blame,
For dread of blame and honours blemishment;
And therefore wisht them without blot or blame,
And to his friend vnwist, for doubt of blame,
And fell away, as feeling secret blame.
And beat his breast vnworthy of such blame,
If heauen, then none may it redresse or blame,
But she with blame would blot, & of due praise depriue.
Gan blame me much for being so vntrew,
Certes sir Knight[s], ye seemen much to blame,
Ne euer for rebuke or blame of any balkt.
Nor any blemish, which the worke mote blame;
As if some blame of euill she did feare,
Thereat that formost matrone me did blame,
A God of seas through his mad mothers blame,
Then blame me not, if I haue err'd in count
That blame it is to him, that armes profest,
Backe to him selfe he gan returne the blame,
Let none then blame me, if in discipline
But that I should die guiltie of the blame,
For oft their lewdnes blotteth good deserts with blame.
In hope ye will not turne misfortune to my blame
Left to her will by his owne wilfull blame,
Oft did she blame her selfe, and often rew,
That neuer did her ill, ne once deserued blame.
And aggrauate the horror of her blame.
Too much am I to blame for that faire Maide,
How cleare I am from blame of this vpbraide:
Amongst all Knights he blotted was with blame,
Least ye therefore mote happily me blame,
With so foule blame, as breach of faith once plight,
To blot the same with blame, or wrest in wicked sort.
Gan him salute, and fowle vpbrayd with faulty blame.
Bloud is no blemish; for it is no blame
Perdie great blame, (then said Sir Calidore)
He with his speare, that was to him great blame,
And gan to blame him for such cruelty
But cleard that stripling of th'imputed blame,
To rayse a lyuing blame against the dead:
I may not certes without blame denie;
How she the blame might salue with coloured disguize.
Of blame, as he did on his Knighthood sweare,
Yet as I well it meane, vouchsafe it without blame.
For first it was to thee reprochfull blame,
I will them soone acquite, and both of blame assoile.
Thus did the courteous Knight excuse his blame,
That much he feared, least reprochfull blame
Albe they worthy blame, or cleare of crime:
Of his late wrongs, in which she oft him blamed
And euer hastie Night he blamed bitterlie.
And euermore she blamed Calepine,
Ne certes mote he greatly blamed be,
And many causelesse caused to be blamed:
For nothing is more blamefull to a knight,
Or blamefull blot, but menaged so well,
From blamefull blot, and free from all that wite,
Bent to reuenge on blamelesse Britomart
In simple truth and blamelesse chastitie,
To get small thankes, and therewith many blames,
Right sore I feare, least with vnworthy blames
And first laide on those Ladies thousand blames,
But sith ye please, that both our blames shall die,
And blames for changing shield:
Yet ill thou blamest me, for hauing blent
Blaming of Fortune, which such troubles threw,
Th'old woman wox half blanck, those words to heare;
Twixt Scudamour and Blandamour:
His name was Blandamour, that did descrie
Whom when as Blandamour approching nie,
Which when as Blandamour beheld, he sayd,
Then tell (quoth Blandamour) and feare no blame,
But Blandamour, whenas he did espie
Blandamour winnes false Florimell,
